title: Treeton Dyke Walking Route

images.title: Derek Whiteley / Treeton Dyke southern corner
images.caption: Treeton Dyke southern corner. A good area for dragonflies on the edge of the lake.

images.title: Andy Gibson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The small lake Treeton Dyke on the South East corner of Sheffield / Rotherham, originally the old course of the River Rother. Surrounded by woods, rivers and fields.

images.title: Water skiing on Treeton Dyke by Martin Speck, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Water skiing on the Dyke

images.title: Treeton Dyke Glimpsed from the Trans Pennine Trail by Jonathan Clitheroe, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Treeton Dyke Glimpsed from the Trans Pennine Trail

images.title: Field of Crops near Treeton by Jonathan Clitheroe, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: A view across the fields to the lake

images.title: Southern entrance to Hail Mary Hill Wood by John Slater, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Southern entrance to Hail Mary Hill Wood on the eastern side of the lake.

images.title: River Rother at Treeton by Steve Howlett, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: River Rother at Treeton. You'll find some pleasant trails along the river just to the west of the lake.

images.title: Reclaimed industrial land by Graham Hogg, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Reclaimed industrial land at Waverley Lakes. At nearby Waverley you will find woodlands and two large lakes set in parkland. Just head a short distance to the west to find some more pleasant footpaths here.

description: This circular walk takes you around Treeton Dyke and woods in Rotherham. The walk starts on the southern side of the lake. From here you can pick up a footpath heading along the eastern side of the water and the adjacent Hail Mary Wood. The trail heads towards Treeton before returning on the western side where there are more paths on Orgreave Common and the Forgemasters Tip. It's easy to extend the walk by heading a short distance east to visit the neighbouring Ulley Country Park. There's another nice waterside trail around the Ulley Reservoir here.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: In nearby Ulley Park there's a small cafe where you could grab a bite to eat after your walk. To the south there's the Oxbow micropub which serves fine real ale. You can find them at 103 Furnace Ln, S13 9XD.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: The area is popular with dog walkers so you'll probably see other owners on your visit. The Oxbow pub mentioned above is also dog friendly.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: The waymarked Rotherham Round Walk passes just to the north of Treeton village. The long distance footpath is a great way of exploring the area around the town. It will take you towards Wentworth Woodhouse which is one of the highlights of the area. Head south along the Sheffield Country Walk and there's more pleasant waterside walking around the large lake in Rother Valley Country Park. Harthill Reservoir and Pebley Reservoir are also located nearby. A few miles to the north there's another lovely lakeside trail and lots of wildlife to see in the popular Thrybergh Country Park. The peaceful woodland trails in Wickersley Woods are also located near here.

display_address: Falconer Lane, Fence, Aston cum Aughton, Orgreave, Rotherham, South Yorkshire, England, S13 9ZE, United Kingdom
